channel.title: Runescape Map Loading
channel.description: Is the current way Jagex is loading the map("mapdata" or XTEA Keys) really more efficient than loading it all on startup? To me it just seems like loading the map every 51 or 103 steps would use more memory than loading it all on startup.

item.title: Runescape Map Loading
item.dc:creator: @light232 light232
item.description:
@light232 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:36, topic:287966”][quote author=light232 link=topic=380730.msg2916248#msg2916248 date=1250459594]

Loading it all on startup would certainly be more demanding.

By loading bit by bit, you may get a small game lagg as it loads yes, but afterwards you can just keep going whilst the game is only holding a minimal map to keep lagg down.

All, in all, its like:

Load Full Map -> Lagg the whole time, especially on shitty systems. (Note: wouldnt it also load all NPCs etc…?)

Load bits of map -> Lagg on loading, then return to a lagg free environment.

npcs and local players + local objects + ground items are all sent by server as u come in view range of them(15 or 16 tiles, idr)
[/quote]

It’s 16.

The value is sent in the range of 0-32, but 16-32 are turned into negative offsets.[/quote]
alright

Read full topic

All, in all, its like:

Load bits of map -> Lagg on loading, then return to a lagg free environment.
[/quote]
npcs and local players + local objects + ground items are all sent by server as u come in view range of them(15 or 16 tiles, idr)[/quote]

It’s 16.

The value is sent in the range of 0-32, but 16-32 are turned into negative offsets.

item.title: Runescape Map Loading
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:33, topic:287966”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=380730.msg2901432#msg2901432 date=1249540612]

Thats the parse landscape method…

Yea it parses it, then inserts each parsed object into the map. I don’t see how ‘loadGameObjects’ is wrong.

Seems like a proper name. Or maybe parseLandscapeObjects.
[/quote]

But since it’s a 2-step process, ‘parsing’ is only half of it. Hence why I used ‘loading’.[/quote]

Good point.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: August 06, 2009, 03:43:14 pm[/size][hr]Ok, I’m still not having any luck. Maybe It’s because I’m going on 40 hours without sleep…

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape Map Loading
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:32, topic:287966”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=380730.msg2901421#msg2901421 date=1249539708]

Thats the parse landscape method…

Yea it parses it, then inserts each parsed object into the map. I don’t see how ‘loadGameObjects’ is wrong.
[/quote]

Seems like a proper name. Or maybe parseLandscapeObjects.[/quote]

But since it’s a 2-step process, ‘parsing’ is only half of it. Hence why I used ‘loading’.

item.title: Runescape Map Loading
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

zyle1992:

Ok. So would the actual objects, or entry ID’s be in byte form, or int form, because there’s only 2 int[][][]'s, one of them is ‘tileHeights’ according to Taharok, Not sure what the other is, while there’s 4-5 byte[][][]'s.

Take a look at my Map 194 class. It is similar to the 317 version, so you should be able to use it for referencing:

http://taharok.pastebin.com/f350c9bc8

You should look at [tt]loadRegionTiles()[/tt] and [tt]loadGameObjects()[/tt]. I do have some testing stuff in there, but you can just ignore it.

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape Map Loading
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

You’re messing with ‘tileHeights’, which stores information about tile height and orientation behavior. It’s data originates from the map files.

@original question, landscapes have always been loaded on a per-several-region basis since 194. This is why “Loading - please wait” exists. The time it takes for that to appear and disappear is the time it takes to unpack the landscape files, parse them, update the map, update the world arrays, then finally re-render it all. It’s actually pretty fast.

Read full topic

And then setting it to 0:

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape Map Loading
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

It is possible. To do it for #317, you’ll need the map_index file. This contains the info necessary to convert region IDs (e.g. (rx << 8) | ry) to entry IDs inside their bare filesystem (‘cache’). Loop through different values for rx and ry, see if the generated region ID has a corresponding entry ID, if so, convert to entry ID. Read that entry’s data and parse it (their Map class has the method). Read in each landscape’s object data and store results, and iterate through results to see if the object ID equals the altar’s, if so, get it’s relative position, and then figure out their absolute position and print it out.

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape Map Loading
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

How so? I’ve been looking into the info in Class7(What i was told handles the World loading bit), and the only thing I’ve been able to get was the current map region that’s loaded(If you tele to 3200 3200, the client’s map region is 401 401, if you tele to 3200 3400 the client’s map region is 401 425, if you tele to 4000 4000, and then tele back to 3192 3400 the clients map region is 400 425). I’ve also cycled through an int[4][105][105] and the output is all negatives, divisible by factors of 8.

Read full topic

@zyle1992 wrote:

The real reason I was wondering, was because I was looking through my 317 data dumps, and I saw that there was a soul talisman, tiara, and altar, and I was wondering if there was a way I could make a for loop that cycles through all the regions, and then checks in each of those regions if the specified object would be found, and if it was, what the coordinates for it were. Is this possible?

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape Map Loading
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Taharok:

The map files are just the instructions for building the map. If you actually wanted to load the polygons, texture them, and try to render them, you would need several gigs of memory, just like he said, etc.

He never mentioned rendering them, but yes, you are right, etc.

Read full topic
